multiple_choice_question.text: What do the two discriminators (D1 and D2) in Δ-GAN aim to achieve?
choices: Generate realistic data samples from both domains.
Map samples from one domain to another.
Distinguish between real data pairs and two kinds of fake data pairs.
Learn the conditional distributions between the two domains.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be observed about the joint distributions learned by Δ-GAN and Triple GAN in Figure 2?
choices: Both Δ-GAN and Triple GAN successfully match the learned joint distributions to the true joint distribution.
Δ-GAN matches the learned joint distributions to the true joint distribution, while Triple GAN fails to do so.
Triple GAN matches the learned joint distributions to the true joint distribution, while Δ-GAN fails to do so.
Both Δ-GAN and Triple GAN fail to match the learned joint distributions to the true joint distribution.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 3 demonstrate about Δ-GAN\'s ability in the context of semi-supervised image classification?
choices: Δ-GAN struggles to generate realistic images from specific classes.
Δ-GAN can disentangle classes but fails to learn meaningful style patterns.
Δ-GAN can disentangle classes and learn meaningful style patterns like background and color.
Δ-GAN\'s generated images lack diversity and rely heavily on injected noise.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the results on the MNIST-to-MNIST-transpose dataset in Figure 4 primarily highlight?
choices: The superior performance of DiscoGAN even with limited paired data.
The importance of providing supervision of domain correspondence for successful image-to-image translation.
The inability of Δ-GAN to accurately translate images between drastically different domains.
The insignificant difference in performance between using 10%, 20%, and 100% paired data with Δ-GAN.
